Description: Rectangular plaque, or scaraboid, carved from steatite; both sides bear an incised decoration; on the upper convex side, representation of a tilapia fish issuing plants from the mouth surrounded by a rope border; on flat underside, representation of a crocodile surmounted by three Bes-figures; cross, diagonal and horizontal hatching details incised in fish and crocodile’s bodies; longitudinally pierced; light brownish glazed surface.
Curator's comments: Two other rectangular plaques were discovered in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 156 and 158). According to B. Jaeger, (Jaeger 1982, 204-205), convex rectangular plaques exist as early as the 18th dynasty, but became popular only under the Ramessid Period. Their terminus ad quem is problematic. They are clearly attested during the 21st dynasty, until Siamun's reign (986–967 BC). However, several pieces of evidence, from Matmar cemetery (Brunton 1948, pl. LXII, 1, 5-6 - mainly 8th-7th century BC) and Naukratis itself, point towards an even later date. Composition representing three Bes-figures or associating a crocodile surmounted by two or more Bes are well attested on convex rectangular plaques of the Ramessid Period (Jaeger 1982, 229, § 1443-1444; Hornung and Staehelin 1976, no. 410). Jaeger suggests that Naukratis specimen should belong to this early period (Jaeger 1982, 205, § 1366, nn. 867-868). Brunton, G. 1948, Matmar, London. Hornung, E. and Staehelin, E. 1976, Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Jaeger, B. 1982. Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 157)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OB.01) (phase 3)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Commitee of)
